settings.spl_text: Widely regarded as the Best hair growth vitamins for mens hair loss

settings.specialized__top_content:
Hair loss in men can start at any age. Most typically though, we find that hair loss and hair thinning begins around the age of 35.

In fact, the American Hair Loss Association published that by the age of 35, nearly two-thirds of the American male population will have some amount of hair loss. By age 50, approximately 85% of men struggle with significant hair loss or thinning hair. Additionally, 25% of men who have male pattern baldness will begin losing their hair before they reach the age of 21.

settings.specialized__what_content: Male Pattern Baldness, also known as Androgenetic Alopecia, is a form of hair loss experienced by men. While Androgenetic Alopecia can also affect women, this form of it causes men to lose their hair in a signature "M" shape.

settings.heading: WHAT CAUSES MALE PATTERN BALDNESS?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Male Pattern Baldness is caused mainly by genetics and a familial history of balding. Inherited (or genetic) male pattern baldness typically has no other side effects or symptoms aside from hair loss.

Researchers have found that Male Pattern Baldness is linked to the male sex hormone (known as androgens) called dihydrotestosterone (DHT). These androgens have many crucial roles to play in the body such as reproductive functions, bone and muscle development, metabolism regulation, and hair growth.

Not all cases of Male Pattern Baldness are because of genetics. Occasionally it is caused by more serious underlying conditions such as cancers, medications, thyroid disease, nutritional deficiencies, and fungal conditions. For this reason, it is important to visit your doctor if you do notice unusual hair loss.

settings.heading: WHAT ARE OTHER CAUSES OF HAIR LOSS IN MEN?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• Hormonal changes
  • Medications
  • Radiation therapy (specifically to the head)
  • Stressful events
  • Damaging hairstyles or hair treatments
  • Scarring
  • Age

settings.heading: HOW DOES MALE PATTERN BALDNESS OCCUR?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Your hair has a natural growth cycle which is made up of three phases: anagen (growth phase), catagen (transitional phase), and telogen (shedding phase). With Male Pattern Baldness the growth cycle, known as anagen, begins to weaken and the hair follicles on the head shrink which overtime produces shorter and thinner strands of hair. As time goes on, the growth cycle for each hair ends and new growth comes to a stop.

settings.heading: IS MALE PATTERN BALDNESS CURABLE?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Male Pattern Baldness is currently not curable, but there are a few things you can do to improve your hair health and growth cycle. They include:

QUIT SMOKING:

Hair loss experienced by both men and women can be caused by smoking. Long term smoking damaged the hair follicle which causes the hair to become thinner and weaker. In addition, smoking restricts healthy blood flow which slows hair growth. For men, this can cause premature Male Pattern Baldness.

REVIEW YOUR MEDICATIONS

There are a number of medications on the market that can contribute to hair loss and hair thinning. Here are a few that are known to cause hair loss:

  • Thyroid medications
  • Weight loss drugs
  • Acne medications containing retinoids
  • Antibiotics
  • Antidepressants
  • Anticlotting drugs
  • Cholesterol-lowering drugs
  • Epilepsy drugs (anticonvulsants)
  • High blood pressure medications
  • Hormone replacement therapy
  • Mood stabilizers
  • Steroids

If you are experiencing unusual hair loss then it is important to review the medications you are taking with a doctor.

MAINTAIN A HEALTHY SLEEP SCHEDULE

Those who neglect incorporating a healthy sleep schedule into their lives has been proven to have many negative side-effects. While most initially it may cause difficulty concentrating, a foggy memory, and weakened strength, overtime it can also cause a vulnerability to infections, an increased risk of Dementia and Alzheimer's Disease, and hair loss.

While you are sleeping, your body produces melatonin which is a hormone that aids in regulating the bodies sleep cycle and hair growth. If you do not have a normal sleep schedule, this hormone will become unbalanced.

REDUCE STRESSORS

Throughout ones life, it is important to manage stress levels for many reasons. Chronic stress can impact almost every system in the body, including: the immune, digestive, reproductive system, and more. It can also affect hair growth over time. Managing stress will improve your overall health and hair growth.

Severe stress caused by a traumatic incident can also interrupt the hair growth cycle causing sudden hair loss. This form of hair loss is known as Telogen Effluvium. Through stress management, your hair will likely return and grow back to its normal state.

HAVE REGULAR SCALP MASSAGES

Increasing blood flow to the scalp has been shown to increase hair growth. For this reason, we recommend doing hot oil treatments and scalp massages regularly.

STOP DAMAGING HAIR TREATMENTS OR STYLES

Tightly pulled hairstyles or having damaging hair treatments done repeatedly can also cause hair loss. This type of hair loss is called traction hair loss, or traction alopecia, and it can often be reversed. To reverse this kind of hair loss you must stop using damaging hairstyles and treatments.

ASSESS YOUR DIET

Eating a healthy, balanced, and nutritious diet is important for all functions in the body, including hair growth. We recommend assessing your diet with a doctor or nutritionist to find out ways you can improve your health.

FIND OUT IF YOU HAVE ANY NUTRITIONAL DEFICIENCIES

Another reason to assess your diet is to find out about any nutritional deficiencies you may have. Having low B12, Riboflavin, or Biotin levels can cause hair loss. By identifying these deficiencies and adding a supplement into your diet, hair loss can often be reversed.
